document.text: xr W a s a s o n o f t h e l a t e H r- D . N. Twyman, of Appomattox. He diejl in New York City, after a brief illness. He is survived by his sister, Mrs. Richard Greenlee, of Scarsdale, New York his brother, Fred W. Twyman, of Camp Lee and his step-mother, Mrs. Annie H. Twyman, of Williamsburg. Active pallbearers were Henry Pack, R. D. Marks, Paul Drinkard, Robert Hubbard, S. A. Lawson and John Harvey.

document.text: Wounded in the gun battle and charged with the crime is Frank Mayberry, 47 of Evergreen. It appears that Tucker was slain on the back porch of the residence in Evergreen in which he and his wife, her mother, and her brother, May berry lived. This shooting apparently occurred sometime after 10 oclock Friday night. Called to the scene from his home in Appomattox, Dr. Christian was on an errand of mercy. From a re construction of the events, it appears that the popular young doctor was shot as he approached the door of the -house. Christians body was found on the walk to the house, and removed only after a terriffic gun battle between the posse and Mayberry. Nearly two hours passed between the shooting of Tucker and the flni arrest, of May- berry- Mayberry was Yelled by a shotgun blast near a garage hide out from which he had fired from 30 to 50 shots from a pistol and a shotgun at the surrounding officers. Mayberry was given medical treat ment here and sent to Rlctnond Saturday morning. His wounds are said not to be serious. The midnight sounding of sirens and the use oi flares to light up the scene attracted the attention of a sizeable gathering of spectators and details of the tragedy have been the topic of interest here since. Funeral services for the victims were held Monday. Serviced for Mr. Tucker were conducted from the Evergreen Baptist Chunch, by the pastor, the Rev. D. L. Bailey. Mili tary services were conducted by the grave by American Legion Post 104. Burial was in the Evergreen Ceme tery. Funeral services for Dr.Christlan were held here Monday at 11 A. M., from Appomattox Court House Pres byterian Church, conducted by his pastor, Dr. Twyman Williams, as sisted by Dr. C. A. Collins, Jr., and the Rev. B. T. Price. A great concourse of friends gath ered for the services. An outpour ing of floral tributes and messages of condolence bore testimony to the esteem in which th1 young physician and his family are held. Son of Dr. D. A. Christian, Jr. the physician began his practice here following service in the Navy during World War II. He occupied the office his father had used for a generation of service to the people of this area. Affectionay known as Young Doctor David, he endeared himself to the public by his skill as a physician and the charm of his personality. He was serving as a member of the Appo mattox Town Council and recently organized a group here to further the cause of physical education at the Appomattox school. As a mark of respect, local busi ness places closed during the funeral hour. A movement has begun to have an appropriate memorial in his hon or. A meeting of friends was held this week to organize a memorial movement, and another meeting will be held Monday night. Dr. Christian is survived .by his wife, the former Louise Campbell of Staunton three children, Mary, 6 Pamela, 4, and David A. Christ ian, IV, 7 months his father, Dr. David A. Christian, Jr and the fol lowing sisters and brother Mrs. George L. Koos, of Tangent, Ore- - gon Mrs. Worth Harris, La Crosse, Florida Mrs. Harold E. Thompson, Jr. Staten Island, New York Mrs. W. J. Byerly, of El Paso, Texas . Mrs. John E. Cox, Jr., Fall Rive  I  Continued on .Page r .-

document.text: Worship services will be at Hollywood Baptist Church Sunday morning July 4 at 9 a.m. Sunday School will follow at 10 oclock. Rev. Paid Balthaaer deliver ed a good message at Hollywood Sunday morning. Friends were deeply grieved to hear of the death of Rev. and Mrs. Clarence Davis infant son. We extend to them our love and deepest sympathy. Deepest sympathy is extend ed the families of Mr. John Ferguson and Mr. Curtis Blackwell. Mrs. Kenneth Deaner and daughters, Delorious Ann and Dawn spent the week end in Newport News with Mrs. loan Mayberry, Mr. and Mrs. Ryland Mayberry and Mrs. Lucy Deaner. Mrs. loan Mayberry accompanied them home for a visit. Mrs. David Austin and Janet were visitors Wednesday mor ning of Mrs. Thomas Woodall and Lisa. Mr. Frank Covington visited Mrs. M. L. Covington and Mrs. W. T. Covington Friday afternoon. Mr. and Mrs. L. L. Webb and Miss Odell Webb called in the W. H. Wingfield home Satur day afternoon. Mr. and Mrs. Twyman Baldwin visited in this home of Mrs. Mary Bagby Saturday night. Visting Mrs. C. R. Ban ton Sunday night were Mr. and Mrs. R. G. Austin and Tom. Mr. and Mrs. H. D. Webb, of Richmond, were guests Sunday of Mr. and Mrs. K. M. Webb and family. Among others visiting Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Woodall and family Sunday were Mr. and Mrs. L. H. Watson, Mr. and Mrs. Scott Sheets and Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Almond. Mr. and Mrs. J. L. Torrence had their children and grand children with them for Fathers Day. Relatives and friends are so glad to hear Mrs. Frank Woodall is home from the hospital. We pray she may soon be well. Miss Joyce Webb spent a few days last week in Lynchburg with Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Woodson. Visting Mr. and Mrs. L. H. Watson Saturday were Mrs. Lee Smith and Mr. and Mrs. Larry Sexton and son. We are very sorry to hear Mr. Bennett Gilliam is back in the Lynchburg Hospital. Rev. and Mrs. Otis Sndtb and Mrs W. T. Covington visited him Sunday afternoon. We wish for him a speedy recovery. Mrs. Ruby Woodson, Lisa and Mrs. M. L. Covington visited Mrs. W. T. Covington last week. Visiting Mr. Frank Coving ton and Mrs. Mary Bagby last week were Mr. and Mrs. James Bartlett, of Texas, Mrs. E. T. Ponton of Roanoke, Rev. Paul Balthaser, David Daniel and Andy Balthaser, Mr. H. W.

document.text: Worship Service  1100 oclock Mid week Prayer Service  730 The Public is invited. Old Concord Presbyterian Church Spout spring, Va. Rev. W. Twyman Williams, Act ing Pastor. Sunday, July 14 10 a.m.  Church School 11 a.m.  Worshippreaching by pastor Sacrament of the Lords Supper C30 Youth Fellowship    New Hope Baptist Church Marvin E. Jacobs, Pastor 10 a.m.  Sunday School 11 a.m.  Morning Worship Message  Christians Paving The Way For Revival 7 p.m.  Training Union 8 p.m.  Evening Worship Message  The Challenge of Christian Conduct The public is cordially invited to worship with us . Bible Baptist Church Sunday School will convene at 10 a.m. with the study being in the second Chapter of Romans. The topic for the morning wor ship service will be entitled When You Have Sepnt All. The Young People will meet at 630 and the study will be Manners and Customs in Bible Lands. The Evening message will be entitled, The Church of Brother- ly Love. This will be the sixth  in a series of messages a on the Seven Churches in the book of Revelation.

document.text: Women of the Church of Ap pomattox Court House Presby terian Church were hostessess Sunday afternoon at an informal reception honoring Dr. and Mrs. W. Twyman Williams. Dr. Wil liams, former pastor of the church, and Mrs. Williams were married this summer. In the receiving line were Rev erend Millard G. Stimpson, pre sent pastor of the church, and Mrs. Stimpson, plus the honor- ees. Mrs. D. E. Caldwell, Sr. presided over the guest book. Mrs. Williams wore an after noon dress of cerulean blue with cocktail hat and bag in black. Her corsage was of white carna tions. The social hall of the church was decorated in green and white with magnolia and oriental holly forming the background for soft candlelight. The refreshment ta ble was set with a hand made cutwork cloth of white. White zinnias, snapdragons, and other fall flowers were used as the centerpiece arrangement. Fruit punch and individual cakes de corated with a bridal motif plus varicolored mints and nuts were served by the ladies of the church.

document.text: Wendy Nadi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Winifred Nash, have returned home from the hospital after having a tonsil lectomy operation on Tuesday. We wish her the best of lock and a speedy recovery. Mrs. Richard Nash and Mrs. Twyman Nash spent Saturday at Holy Land U.S.A. near Bedford. Mr. and Mrs. Richard Nash visited Mr. and. Mrs. David Carson and Susan Sunday afternoon. Mr. Troy Tucker of Welling ton, Delaware spent the week end here visiting relatives. Mr. Shelbys Tuckers sister has moved here and is living in Appomattox. Mr. and Mrs. Shelby Tucker had lunch with Mr. and Mrs. Edd Collins and Eric of Lynchburg on Sunday. Mrs. Dennis Arnold and children visited Mr. and Mrs. Shelby Tucker Sunday after noon. Chiquita Tucker is celebra ting her sixth birthday today. Congratulations to Chiquita. Shes the daughter of Mr. and

document.text: Well, we can! The 11th graders re ----- ae Welch Boney, diec and  at her home here Tuesday night Neal following an illness of three months, .,..j was the widow of Robert Bruce Boney. She was born in Butler, Ind May 1, 1881, and moved to Appo mattox County seven years ago from Blackstone. She taught in the county schools since makng her residence here. She is survived by one son, and Anne daughter-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. R, B J. E.  Boney, Jr., and a granddaughter, Virginia Miss Nancy Carol Boney.  Mrs. Jennie Funeral services will be held a F. Trent and the home on Church Street Friday A. M. Interment will be in and Mrs.  Liberty Cemetery. Dr. W. Twyman of Rich-. Williams will officiate.

Phillip Benton have returned Mr. and Mrs. Armon Thoina home from the hospital after and boys were supper guests of having his tonsils removed. document.text: We welcome our new pastor and family to Central Baptist Church. Rev. Menser preached his first sermon on Sunday night. Our deepest sympathy goes out to the family and love ones of Mrs. Hungate and also to the family of Mr. Rush. Stewart and Robin Mann spent Saturday night with their grandparents Mr. and Mrs. Henry Mann. Mr. and Mrs. Roy Layne and Missy of Lynchburg visited Mr. and Mrs. Richard Nash over the week end. Mr. Ray Layne and Mrs. Twyman Nash spent Saturday in North Carolina. Mrs. Lulu Mann is in the hospital. We wish her the best of luck and a speedy recovery. Mr. and Mrs. Skinney Wooldridge visited Mr. and Mrs. Emery Mullins on Sunday. Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Nash and girls visited Mr. and Mrs. Nelson Mann and boys Sunday evening. Randy St. John spent the week end-in the home of Mr. and Mrs. Pete Banton and Phillip. Keith, Tony and Mike Mann visited in this home on Sunday afternoon. Mr. and Mrs. George D. Nash and children were supper guest of Mr. and Mrs. EUiott Nash and Dawn on Saturday. Sunday visitors in this home were Mr. and Mrs. Nelson Mann and Mr. Loyd Nash. Mrs. Nelson Mann visited Mr. Jimmy Howard in the hospital on Thursday. Jimmy came home on Monday. Mrs. Richard Nash and Mrs. Clarence Jones are on the sick Ifyt. Glad they are feeling JdvV.n oJ Mrs. Cedi Nash and Cecila Nash visited her parents Mr. and Mrs. A. B. Evans Jr. on Sunday. Jennifer Nash ate lunch with Dawn Kerr on Sunday. Cecil Nash visited Mrs. Jimmy Howard and family on Sunday. Mrs. Vernie Jones is not feeling well at this time. We hope shell soon be better. Mr. and Mrs. Shelby Tucker motored to Peaks of Otter and Parkway on Sunday and also visited Mr. and Mrs. Edd Collins and Eric Sunday. Mrs. Jordan Tucker and girls visited Mr. and Mrs. Shelby Tucker and Mr. James Tucker and Mr. James Tucker and Clara Sunday evening.

document.text: WE USE ONLY THE BEST MATERIALS AND LABOR. M il We invite friends and relatives to come and lets honor aU fathers. Mrs. Richard Nash, Windy Nash and Mr. and Mrs. Ray Layne and Missy were supper guest of Mr. and Mrs. David Carson Sunday night. Jackie Dale Kerr, Keith, Tony and Mike Mann spent Saturday with their grand mother, Mrs. Elliott Nash and Dawn Kerr. Mr. E. R. Ferguson continues about the same. Mrs. Twyman

We Presbyterians are glad to welcome the Home Mission Messenger again, commencing with the October number we expect to get it all winter. Mr. E W. Hubard and Mr otan A Twyman went to Rich raond last week on business connected with the schools. Abraham Davis and Richard Taylor have been serving out a jail sentence on the charge of having set fire to some proper ty near Bethlehem church Mr Ashley Grigg, jr., has come home from France and Ir. Mark Teeter, who has been at Panama for some time, has also come home, on furlough. Sow in dust, reap we must is an old saying, aud if there is anything in it the wheat and oat crop nhould be a record breaker. I passed through parts of Campbell, Nelson, Amherst and Buckingham and found that the rain was a general one so far a-, these places were con cerned and now the farmers will resume the sowing of grass and grain with the hope that these crops will get a start be fore winter sets in Some new corn has changed hands at prices varying from 6 to 8 Old corn sold on the local market for 10. Smoked sides of bacon and shoulders sold at 35j, but there has been a sharp decline in the prices of bulk meat. I offered 50c a barrel to gath er apples and couldnt get one mothers son to gather them. They will buy the apples, all right, and pay the cash for them. I offered one party to give them a lot if they would gather them, but everyone is too busy now to do anything, so a few just sit by and do nothing.

document.text: We are very sorry Mr. H. W. Jenkins is on our sick list but we pray he may soon be well. Mr. and Mrs. Twyman Baldwin and Mr. and Mrs. Robert Jenkins visited Mr. and Mrs. Jenkins Sunday. Mr. and Mrs. Bennett Gilliam of Farmville are visiting Mrs. W. T. Covington and other relatives. A good many were at church Saturday night for the special prayer service for peace. Mr. Raymond Franklin was operated on Monday at Vir ginia Baptist Hospital. His many friends wish for him a very speedy recovery. We were very sorry to hear of the death last week of Mr. Willis Inge. Deepest sympathy is extended his love ones. Supper guest Friday night of Mr. and Mrs. Bennett Gilliam of Farmville were Mrs. J. L. Torrence, Mrs. W. T. Coving ton, Mrs. Otis Smith and Mrs. James Conner. Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Wood- all and daughter, Lisa of Covington spent the week end with Mrs. C. J. Bagby. Mr. and Mrs. Dallas Mangus of Lynch burg spent Saturday in this home. Others calling were Mr. and Mrs. W. H. Wingfield, Miss Julia Wingfield and Mrs. Bill Watson and son, William. Mrs. Thomas Woodall, Lisa, and Mrs. Dallas Mangus visited Mr. and Mrs. W. H. Wingfield and family Saturday afternoon. Mr. and Mrs. Bill Watson and William were visitors Tuesday night of Mr. and Mrs. W. F. Woodall in Lynchburg. Mr. Woodall isnt feeling well but we hope he may soon be well. We are very sorry to learn Mrs. F. O. Covington of Lynchburg is sick, but we pray she may soon be better. She has a sister is very ill in S. C. We wish for her a very speedy recovery. We were very sorry to hear of the death last week of Mr. and Mrs. Watt Morriss son. Much sympathy is extended the family.

document.text: Watt Stanley, of Clifton Forge was home last week-end. Mrs. T. B. Collins spent the week- - nd in Portsmouth. Mrs. C. F. James spent the week end in Richmond. Miss Rachel Harvey, who is em-  loyed by the State Highway De partment at Chatham, has been trans ..erred to Fincastle. Lewis McDearmon spent- yester day in Richmond. Mr. and Mrs. C. M. Harvey and Mrs. H. A. Mitchell spent Friday in the -home of Mrs. H. A. Torrence. Mrs. W. D. Patterson spent Sun day in Lynchburg. Miss Eula Mae Carter, of Lynch- .-org spent the week-end at her home here. Miss Catherine Torrenae spent the week-end in Lynchburg. Mr. and Mrs. H. A. Torrence, liss Annie Torrence, Jim Lucado J, H.  Torrence and Misses Helen  nd Catherine Torrence spent Sun day in the home of Mrs. David Har- _ l s  in Lynchburg. Mrs. Emma Nowlin spent some imerlast week with Mrs. R. W. Morris. Capt. and Mrs. Charles F. James, Jr., of Fortess Monroe, have an nounced the birth of a daughter, Barbara Scott, born at the Medical Hospital of .Virginia, Richmond, on Friday September 11. Mr. and Mrs. F. C. Dresser ac- ompanied their son, Frankie, to V. M. , Lexington, Monday where be matriculated as a cadet. Mrs. James Carson and son, of Lynchburg were visitors in Appo mattox Saturday. Robert Allen Sears, who has been visiting his roommate in New York, hab returned to his home here nd will remain for -a few days be- ore leaving for V. P. I., Blacks burg. Emmett Dinkins, of Portsmouth, and Twyman Conner, of Lynchburg pent Friday night in the home of Mrs. T. U. Conner. Mr. and Mrs. R. B. Hudgins and Miss Patty Featherston spent sever al days this week in Richmond.

document.text: Washington.Weather maps to eight layers, showing wlint conditions the aviator may expect when he lies hath low and high, are now being made regularly as a part of the official government weather report. Ground weufher observations alone have been found to be Inadequate for dying use. and the hlgh-altltude ob servations have also been found use ful in making the regular weather forecasts. In fact, the wenther seems to brew at the higher levels, and the observations, obtained by small bal loons and kites, often give Informa tion unobtainable nt the level of the earths surface. 43 Balloon Stations Send Data. The data used In the npper-atr weather maps come to the weather bureau from forty-three halloon sta tions throughout the country. The army has eighteen, while the navy tins ten balloon stations and one air- nlane observer. The wenther burenu also receives alr-aloft reports of temperature and humidity from five stations where kites are sent up with raeteorollglcal In struments. As kites are dependent upon wind, the wenther bureau Is about to try out a small captive bal loon. lust large enough to carry the oecessury Instruments, at Due West, S. C for use when Fhe air Is light. Helicopters will replace balloons and kites In the future. In the opinion ot Mr. Mitchell. Slvew Bumpy Air. Bumpy air, which makes rough rid ing for flyers. Is dearly shown by these kite reports. One recent re- laid from Orosheck, Texas, showed three strata of air-In an altitude of 1,800 meters. A meter Is a little more than three feet. The complete aero- logical observation map gives wind direction, velocity, kind and direction of clouds, and visibility as at surface. 250 meters above, 500 meters. 1,000 meters, 1,500 meters, 2,000 meters, 3,000 meters and 4,000 meters above. The balloons sometimes achieve much higher altitudes. The origin of the wind, whether polar or tropical. Is also known to the weather bureau and aids In weather txrar its entirely jvblcHif the bittsr outburst of feeling which was so character istic four years ago. It is alleged that such proceedings as were carried on four years ago were very distasteful to many of the citizens of the county and for that reason the rank and file of voters are slow to express their choice for fear of the recurrence of hostile feeling. While no doubt man j have de cided views a to whom they will vote for, but little or no pub lic demonstrations have taken place throughout the county and while a few public gatherings have been held, the attendance at these meetings have been small and little interest in such meetings have been manifested. For the house of delegates, Col. A. J. Terrell is opposed by D- N. Gannaway, both of Buck ingham. Colonel Terrell being a candidate for what is called the organizations forces and Mr, Gannaway representing t h e antis. In this, like other county contests, there has been no issue and the fight hangs chiefly on personalities. In some quarters, the question of the short ballot issue has been in jected in which Mr. Gannaway ias declared himself as opposed to the short ballot, while no such statement has come from Mr. Terrell other than he is for the administration policies. As the short ballot, is an administra tion policy, however, it is regard ed that Mr. Terrell is for it, and su far, that is about the main is sue involved between the two candidates for that office. With but four more days be fore election more activity is teen on every hand and the poli tical pot is warming up to a con siderable degree in some of the local fights. For treasurer R. L. Burke is opposed by Dr. D. N. r wyman for commissioner of revenue Richard OBrien is op posed by George Purdum for supervisor Don Moses and C. S McDearmon are both candidates for Southside district to be made vacant by D. N. Twyman, the ncumbent, who is running for treasurer in Cloverhill district F. A- OBrien, the incumbent, is opposed by E. M. Drinkard, ant n Stonewall district Sam Ander on, the incumbent, is being op- tost d by A. B. Thornhill. During the past few days quite i contention has arisen over an ict of the registrars who have either by error of ignorantly sent rat two different kinds of in- structions to voters who wish to I vote by mail, this vote will  be heavy. Every available voter a being solicited for his or her vote whether they are in the
